Step 4 - Summarized text chunk: "SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Congress finds that free trade agreements improve income and prosperity by increasing competition, reducing costs, and promoting economic growth. APEC member economies aim for free and open trade by 2020 for developing countries and 2010 for developed countries. Political stability is crucial for US interests in the Pacific Rim region, as the financial crisis in Asia has disrupted US export growth. Free trade agreements help open markets for US goods and services amid global economic pressures towards protectionism. The United States aims to leverage market opening measures for its goods and services by working with long-time allies in the Asia-Pacific region like New Zealand, Australia, and Singapore. Building closer ties with friendly countries will be beneficial as trade negotiations for liberalization progress in the next century. The US must continue promoting its interests through aggressive trade and investment agendas in the region. The United States aims to promote its interests in the Asia-Pacific region through aggressive trade and investment negotiations. Bilateral trade talks can positively influence multilateral and regional trade negotiations by expanding common areas of agreement. Resolving trade and investment disputes with Pacific Rim countries through mutually agreed-upon disciplines is more effective than issue-by-issue confrontations under trade remedy laws. Free trade agreements between the United States and Pacific Rim countries aim to enhance cooperation and ensure mutually beneficial economic and political relations. These agreements will help stabilize the bilateral trade balance by improving market access and understanding for US firms in Pacific Rim markets. The United States trade policy with eligible Pacific Rim countries is outlined in Section 2. The United States aims to eliminate tariff and nontariff barriers through bilateral free trade agreements with Pacific Rim countries. Nontariff barriers include regulatory obstacles, lack of protection for intellectual property, and arbitrary standards. The United States aims to address nontariff barriers such as regulatory obstacles, intellectual property protection, and unfair trade practices like price controls and restrictions on listings for government formularies. SEC. 3. PRENEGOTIATION CONSULTATIONS. Within 60 days of enacting the Act, the President will consult with eligible Pacific Rim countries. If feasible, a ministerial meeting will be requested to discuss free trade agreement negotiations. The International Trade Commission will provide advice within 6 months after each ministerial meeting. The United States International Trade Commission will advise the President on the economic effects of providing duty-free treatment for articles from eligible Pacific Rim countries on US industries and consumers. SEC. 4. MINISTERIAL MEETING RECOMMENDATIONS. The President recommends establishing a council of public and private sector officials to review trade aspects and issue a report on the bilateral relationship within 6 months. The President proposes establishing a council to review trade aspects and issue a report on the bilateral relationship within 6 months, including information on disputed practices and prospects for a free trade agreement. The President will determine the feasibility and desirability of negotiating free trade agreements with eligible countries. The President will determine the feasibility and desirability of negotiating free trade agreements with eligible Pacific Rim countries based on reports from bilateral councils. The determination will be submitted to the Senate and House committees. The President will consider various factors in determining the feasibility and desirability of establishing a free trade area with an eligible country, including membership in the World Trade Organization, interest in negotiating a bilateral free trade agreement with the US, trade liberalization efforts, affinity for US trade policy objectives, and active participation in international trade preparations. The country has shown support for US trade policy objectives, actively participates in World Trade Organization meetings, works to eliminate export requirements, seeks harmonization of standards in APEC, and increases economic opportunities. The country supports US trade policy objectives, participates in WTO meetings, eliminates export requirements, harmonizes standards in APEC, increases economic opportunities, and resolves trade disputes with the US. The United States will benefit from improved dispute settlement mechanisms and enhanced market access by eliminating trade barriers in a specific country. The President must consult with specific Congressional committees regarding the implementation of the Act. The Act defines eligible Pacific Rim countries as WTO members and APEC economies.
